data.Name: Dr. Indhu Varatharajan
data.description: Dr. Indhu Varatharajan recently completed her Ph.D. as a DLR-DAAD PhD Fellow in Planetary Science at Institute of Planetary Research, German Aerospace Center (DLR), Berlin.  In her PhD she focused on the integrated spectroscopy approach (laboratory spectroscopy, telescope observations, orbital data analysis) to understand the abundance and distribution of silicate and volatile (sulfide) mineralogy of Mercury to support spectrometers onboard ESA-JAXA BepiColombo and NASA MESSENGER missions. Her PhD is funded by the MERTIS payload team onboard BepiColombo mission and she is one of the Co-Investigators of the MERTIS instrument. She received her Masters as a Commonwealth Scholar in Planetary Science from University College London (UCL), UK in 2015 and Bachelors in Geoinformatics Engineering from College of Engineering, Guindy (CEG), Anna University, India in 2012. Before Masters, she worked at Planetary Science and Exploration (PLANEX) Division at Physical Research Laboratory (PRL), Department of Space, India where she was part of the study team in preparation for Mangalyaan mission to Mars and also published her work on Chandrayaan-1 lunar data analysis on mapping of mineralogy of young volcanism of Moon. In 2018, she was part of the Frontier Development Laboratory (FDL) Europe team that demonstrated automated mapping of informal settlements using ML techniques on Sentinel-2 datasets. Dr. Varatharajan served as the first Elected Chair of Europlanet Early Career Network (2018-2021) and was also elected Councilor of Royal Astronomical Society (2019). Indhuâ€™s CV can be accessed via https://bit.ly/indhuCV

data.Name: Hari Prasath
data.description: I am Hari Prasath, author of Spaceman, a science fiction book with a masters degree in space systems engineering from ISAE SUPAERO, Toulouse, France. Space has been the driving factor of my life. I believe that the deep space holds the answers to our existence and purpose in life. Currently, I am working as a scientific engineer at Stellar Space Studies, Toulouse, France in the fields of the gravity field and climatic sciences. I will continue developing myself for the space sector in future and hopefully, make a good change in the sector.

data.Name: The Martian Movie Discussion
data.Description: In this era, there are a lot many people who dream of colonizing Mars and consider it to be a viable plan to adopt for the future. For such people, the movie â€œThe Martianâ€ would be a good place to start with. It describes how inhospitable a world Mars actually is and beautifully depicts the challenges that lie ahead. A detailed summary of the movie was presented, following which the various scientific concepts underlying habilitation on Mars were discussed.

data.Name: Interstellar Movie Discussion
data.Description: Interstellar is arguably one of the best sci-fi movies ever directed. A beautiful blend of extreme physics and emotions, many aspects of Interstellar have often been difficult for the general audience to grasp. Our discussion started with a comprehensive narration of the storyline followed by a descriptive elucidation of how 4-D spacetime works in the movie and how Gravity acts as a force that could transcend dimensions!

data.Name: Kodaikanal Solar Observatory - A virtual tour
data.Description: Located amidst the scenic mountain slopes of Kodaikanal, lies the well-renowned Kodaikanal Solar Observatory. Visiting the observatory would have made one great trip, but the pandemic had mandated that we stay indoors! Luckily we had the great opportunity to interact (virtually) with Dr. Ebenezer Chellasamy, a scientist from the Indian Institute of Astrophysics. He showed us the various telescopes and instruments housed by each facility at the observatory. He also highlighted the various research opportunities available for students, at the observatory.

data.Name: IDSW-21: Light Pollution and Astrophotography
data.Description: Gazing into the infinite depth of the night sky makes us feel diminished amidst the vast sea of stars. The art of capturing the beauty of the night sky using a camera has played a key role in popularizing astronomy amongst the public. But wait. What if you cannot see and capture the stars anymore? Mr. Sathyanarayanan shares his experience as a professional astrophotographer in coping up with light pollution.

data.Name: IDSWâ€™21: A Talk on Constellations
data.Description: Humans have mapped the night sky for millennia. Different cultures had charted the night skies in unique ways. We share an extricable link with constellations and their history. This talk explored the rich history behind the Modern Constellations that we have internationally adopted and the folklore behind them.

data.Name: IDSW-21: Interview with Save Our Stars
data.Description: â€œSave Our Stars (SOS)â€ is a Delhi-based organization that advocates for Night-Sky conservation and sustainable lighting practices. We were delighted to interview Mr. Deep Anand, founder of SOS, who detailed the inception of his organization and its mission to save the night sky.

data.Name: IDSW-21: Impact on Wildlife
data.Description: Light pollution affects the natural cycle of biological life forms (including ourselves!) in significant ways. We were honored to have Ms.Meghaa S, an environmental educator at Pitchandikulam forest, Auroville, Pondicherry. She explained in great detail the impact posed by light pollution on insects and other nocturnal wildlife and the steps that we can adopt to minimize them.

data.Name: IDSW-21: Intro Talk
data.Description: We are slowly losing the night sky to blinding Artificial Light At Night (ALAN). Light Pollution has become a profound anthropogenic phenomenon that we get to experience in our everyday lives. The fact that you rarely get to see stars while living in the middle of the city is because of light pollution. The International Dark-Sky Week (IDSW) is a week-long celebration of the night sky conducted by the International Dark-sky Association (IDA) every year. The Astro Club of AU is proud to organize â€œRe-Light the Starsâ€ in collaboration with IDA to support its cause.

data.Name: Space-O-Pedia: AU+CIT
data.Description: An online quiz competition on the topic â€œLight years and types of Asteroidsâ€ was held in collaboration with the Space Club of CIT.

data.Name: Moon Observation and Astrophotography Workshop
data.Description: A hands-on workshop on Moon Observation and Astrophotography was conducted in collaboration with Green Brigade, the Eco club of CEG, as a part of ECOSUMMIT 2020. The basics of Astrophotography were discussed by Mr. Sathyanarayanan, a professional astrophotographer based in Chennai. Then we were taught how to use a DSLR in combination with a telescope.

data.Name: Hands-on Telescope Workshop 2.0
data.Description: In conjunction with Space Chennai, a hands-on telescope workshop was held. We were given a refractor telescope and instructed on how to study the Moon and its craters. Then we looked at Jupiter and Saturn using a pair of Dobsonian telescopes. After that, there was a discussion over the development of craters on the Moon.

data.Name: Zero-Shadow Day
data.Description: The phenomenon of Zero Shadow Day was observed in Chennai. An open event was conducted and we were addressed by Dr. Gopal Narayanan, Principle Investigator, the Event Horizon Telescope.

data.Name: Astro Coffee - A talk on KalamSat and Neutrinos
data.Description: We were delighted to have Space Kidz India conduct a Project Display session of their femto satellites.   We were addressed by Dr. Srimathy, Mr. Rifath Shaarook, and other KALAMSat team members about the inception of their organization and its mission. This was followed by a group discussion on Neutrinos and The Fermi Paradox by Dr.Indhumati, Cheif Scientist, India Based Neutrino Observatory.

data.Name: International Asteroid Search Campaign 2019
data.Description: A team representing the Astro Club of AU participated in the 2-week long asteroid search campaign. We obtained a â€œprovisional discoveryâ€ while performing analysis on the provided data using the tool given to us.

data.Name: Hands-on Telescope Workshop
data.Description: A hands-on telescope workshop was conducted in collaboration with Space Chennai. Participants were provided with a refractor telescope and we were taught to observe the Moon and its craters. Then we used a pair of Dobsonian telescopes to observe Jupiter and Saturn. This was followed by a discussion on Crater formation on the Moon.

data.Name: A Visit to Birla Planetarium
data.Description: The visit to Birla Planetarium started with the Planetarium show, in which a star projector explained the Solar System and its composition. It was an enthralling experience and it captivated us for the whole show. Then, we watched a 3D show about the "Age of Dinosaurs" with the theme of Time Travel. "Science in a Sphere" was entertaining and it gave an insightful explanation about El Nino and the alarming issue of ocean pollution. Then we entered into the other exhibits representing different fields of science, Biology, Nuclear energy, Mathematics, and basic sciences.

data.Name: World Space week - Women in Space
data.Description:
Astro club of AU held an interactive Sessions on Astronomy with U & I charity foundation on Sunday morning with a bunch of enthusiastic kids. They were eager to learn concepts, divulge into the knowledge to explore our Universe, and get to know our solar system & our home, Earth. It was a pleasure for our club to teach and get acquainted with young astrophiles, willing to learn new things.

We thank you for the opportunity and would like to meet up with the kids for another exciting session.

data.Name: World Space week - Women in Space - Offline mode
data.Description:
On the occasion of International Space Week (October 4-10), the Astroclub of AU organised offline and online workshops on "Introduction to Astronomy and Space Sciences".

Astronomy being one of the most astonishing fields of Science but is often   overlooked among students so the Astroclub of AU conducted this hands on workshop to spread awareness and spark an interest in this domain for our students.

data.title: Hypothetical Ninth Planet: Planet X
data.content:
Despite our Solar System’s close proximity to Earth relative to the rest of the universe, there is far too much that humans do not know about it yet. One such deep-rooted mystery is Planet Nine. It’s a theoretical, undiscovered giant planet in the far reaches of our solar system. Researchers said that only a large and very distant planet could keep all the orbits confined to part of the solar system and the theory of Planet Nine was born. The presence of Planet Nine has been hypothesized to explain everything from the tilt of the sun’s spin axis to the apparent clustering in the orbits of small, icy asteroids beyond Neptune.

This putative world would be about 10 times the size and mass of the Earth. One year on this planet would last 17,000 years on Earth and it would travel as far away as 93 billion miles from the sun, where it would take light a week to arrive.

This hypothetical giant world beyond Neptune orbits at a 30-degree angle to other planets and this might be a possible reason for a tilt in our solar system. Though the eight planets orbit in an essentially flat plane around the sun, the plane itself rotates at nearly a six-degree angle, making it look like the sun itself is angled. A giant planet with a strange orbit, about 30 degrees off the other planets’ plane, could account for that wobble. Planet Nine would also alter the source regions and the inclination distribution of comets.

We might think how could a hypothetical planet be responsible for making the sun appear to tilt at an angle but essentially this Planet Nine is so massive, thereby the solar system has no choice but to slowly twist out of alignment.

The Kuiper Belt is a circumstellar disc in the outer Solar System, extending from the orbit of Neptune at 30 astronomical units to approximately 50 AU from the Sun. Planet Nine is also expected to be a part of the Kuiper Belt. These extreme Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs), which have elongated orbits that come very close to and stray very far from the sun, would probably not be affected by the large planets of the solar system. The astronomers have also noticed that some planets of the solar system (namely Pluto (now a dwarf planet), Uranus, and Neptune) have very simple orbital ratios suggesting that they are in resonance with an unseen massive planet.

Many of these KBOs have been discovered to have very elliptical and tilted orbits, like Pluto. Mathematical calculations and detailed computer simulations have shown that the orbits we see in the Kuiper Belt can only be created if Neptune originally formed a few AU closer to the sun and migrated outward to its present orbit. Neptune’s migration explains the pervasiveness of highly elliptical orbits in the Kuiper Belt.

We have discovered billions of objects in the cosmos but why aren’t we able to spot such a big planet?

KBOs do not emit their own light. They only reflect light from the sun. Thus, detecting such objects at larger distances is extremely difficult. If you move 10 times farther away from KBO, it will become 10,000 times fainter. KBOs on elliptical orbits will spend most of their time at the most distant parts of their orbits. So, while it is easy to find KBOs on elliptical orbits when they are close to the sun and bright, these KBOs spend most time being much fainter which makes them harder to detect.

However, some are skeptical that this is a full-blown planet, with some suggesting that Planet 9 is instead a grapefruit-sized ultra-concentrated black hole (referring to black holes formed in the early universe) with a mass of five to ten times that of the Earth. They also state that there must be a halo of dark matter around the black hole in that scenario.

There have been several published predictions for its location, but none of the search teams has yet discovered it. Even if Planet Nine isn’t there, it has sparked a lot of interest in the outer Solar System. There is still only indirect evidence in favor of Planet Nine. Many beautiful and surprising objects remain to be discovered in the mysterious outer solar system with an optimistic hope of spotting them in the near future.

data.title: A Fairytale rule?
data.content:
Almost everyone is familiar with the tale of ‘Goldilocks and the three bears.’ Though there are several versions of the tale, the storyline is that a small girl enters a forest by chance, roams around, and finds a small cottage, of the three bears. When she arrives at the cottage, it was empty as the bears go out for a walk. She enters the cottage and being hungry, she sees three bowls of porridge on a table, one too hot, one too cold, and one just right. It goes the same for the chairs and beds. One too big, one too small, and one just right. From this, we get our fairy tale rule known as the Goldilocks principle. It is a doctrine that supports the just-right-amount for the conception of existence, as a given.

Goldilocks principle states that in a given sample, there may be entities belonging to extremes, but there will always be an entity belonging to the average. Or in other words, in a sample, there will always be a U-shaped distribution. When the effects of the principle are observed, it is known as the Goldilocks effect. As it constitutes the just right or the desired, this principle has various applications in several fields including astronomy, biology, economics, engineering, and developmental psychology.

In astronomy, we use this Goldilocks principle to find the range of distance from a star within which a planet can be so that it can have and maintain the just-right temperature for water to exist in liquid form. The range zone is known as the Goldilocks zone, in which life can be supported. Based on this idea, the Goldilocks zone of our solar system has a range from Venus to Mars having Earth in the most habitable distance. So, under this perception, Venus and Mars also have the possibility of having liquid water on the surface. Planetary scientists think that Venus may have had water on its surface but due to the extreme greenhouse effect caused by carbon dioxide and other gases, the planet’s temperature on its surface is about 462 ̊C which allows water to exist but only in a vapor form. Mars, as a result of its atmosphere being stripped away due to an ancient solar wind, has a low air pressure and thus water cannot exist as a liquid for a long. Thus, the zone may not always contain habitable planets as the circumstances are different.

The scientists can take the Goldilocks zone as an assumption for finding Earth-like celestial objects with the possibility of liquid water in them supporting life. But they may or may not be habitable despite falling in the Goldilocks zone. So, Earth is just right for us humans and for other fellow species like the ultimately invaluable treasure trove, and we must appreciate the unbelievable odds of our existence in this universe of probability.

data.title: ALL YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT GEMINIDS-2020 !!
data.content:
“As the leaves turn brown and the days cold, the wind signals the year coming to a close.”

Alas! What a year has it been! Ravaged by wildfires, battered by tropical cyclones, and plagued by a never-ending pandemic, I - Humanity, have endured yet another year of hardships. Paying the brunts of the mistakes that I had committed upon my planet, I looked up to the stars with my hopes drained, trying to make sense of my existence. And that’s when I found myself under a shower of answers from the skies. The noblest of all - The showers of Gemini. The streaks of light, rekindling my hope, that there’s still a way to save my planet.

And it is this hope that I wish to instill upon my fellow Terrans …

"THE MAGNIFICENT GEMINIDS"

Geminids over the Teide, Canary Islands

        The Geminids are a prolific annual meteor shower that reigns supreme over the night sky during the first two weeks of December. These dazzling balls of light are renowned across the globe as one of the best showers of the year that produce a spectacle like no other. Best viewed from the Northern Hemisphere, the Geminids are known for their persistent trains of more than 100 meteors every hour!

        Contrary to the moniker of “shooting stars 🌠”, meteor showers are totally unrelated to stars. Rather, they are produced by a phenomenon happening close to Earth, in its upper atmosphere. For instance, the Geminids are produced by the debris leftover by the asteroid 3200 Phaethon, as it orbits around the Sun.

The orbital path of 3200 Phaethon

        When the Earth intersects the orbit of this asteroid every year, in the month of December, the debris leftover in its orbital track slams into our planet’s atmosphere, hence producing these brilliant meteors.

Where and When can I spot the Geminids?

        Though the shower remains active between the 4th and 17th of December, its peak activity falls on the morning of the 14th. That’s when one could spot more than 120 meteors per hour. Trying to spot them on the weekend before 14th is equally promising.

        The Geminids can be spotted grazing the sky, in any direction. But when traced back, these streaks of light seem to emerge from a particular point located in the constellation of Gemini - The Twins (hence the name Geminids).

        This point is known as the Radiant of the shower. As depicted in the constellation map above, the radiant lies below the star θ-Gem. Even if one cannot find the radiant in the sky, identify the constellation of Gemini by looking out for its brightest stars- Castor and Pollux. Another guide would be the Constellation of Orion (finding which is relatively easier); left of which lies Gemini.

Gemini constellation.

The Gemini (and hence the radiant) rises above the eastern horizon by 8 PM IST every night. But the best time to go out hunting for a meteor would be after midnight, ideally around 2 AM. That’s when the radiant climbs up to its highest position in the night sky and gets close to the zenith (the uppermost point in the sky), where there will be very few obstacles that could block your vision of a meteor and less light pollution as well!

Another added advantage is that the Moon 🌑 wouldn’t be around during the Geminid Peak as it would be in its waning crescent phase and closer to the Sun.

Well, now I guess you are ready to spot the Geminids. But before packing your backpack, here are some tips that you could consider.

Some Noteworthy Tips to spot the Geminids

  • Dark Sky is your best friend. Always stay away from city lights (and any artificial sources of light) for the best meteor watching experience. You can even hold an umbrella behind you to hide your eyes from stray light.
  • You could use a red torch to navigate around your selected spot, as it won’t affect your eyes’ ability to spot faint stars and meteors (Dark Adapt).
  • Make sure that you spend at least an hour or two watching the meteors. They arrive in spurts and lulls, so a period of inactivity for a while is natural. It is important to note that your eyes can take as long as 20 minutes to Dark adapt.

Geminids over Custer State Park, South Dakota, USA.

  • Don’t worry about locating the radiant. The meteors arrive throughout the sky. So make sure that you provide yourself with a wide field of view. You could lay down on a reclining chair and look up. And you wouldn’t need any special equipment to spot meteors. Eyes that are well adapted to the darkness are just sufficient.
  • And most importantly, carry a friend along. The more the merrier 😄. What's better than having a good night out with your pals while the stars are raining down upon you !!

Well, that's it from me...

Happy Meteor Hunting 🌠🌠 !!

data.title: KEPLER SPACE TELESCOPE â€“ THE EXO PLANET HUNTER
data.content:
What a decade for scientific development! From the discoveries of potentially habitable alien planets to the detection of a tiny new moon and jaw-dropping lunar and solar eclipses, astronomical research has not only made extraordinary strides but also raised new and tantalizing questions for the future.

One such hero which contributed its lifetime to Astro-discovery is the Kepler Space Telescope.

The Kepler Space telescope (a retired space telescope) was a space observatory launched by NASA to find planets outside our solar system with a particular focus on finding planets that might resemble Earth. Delta II Rocket (which carried Kepler Telescope) was launched on March 7, 2009from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida. The telescope was placed into an Earth-trailing heliocentric orbit.

Kepler Telescope has an instrument called a photometer that continuously monitors the brightness of approximately 150,000 main sequence stars in a fixed field of view. These data were transmitted to Earth to be analyzed and detect periodic dimming caused by these exoplanets. Gazing at a fixed spot in the constellation Cygnus, it monitored around 100,000 stars. Kepler's ability to look at the changing brightness of stars was exploited for the Pleiades, a well-known cluster of stars that is only 400 light-years away and visible to the naked eye. Kepler's 115-degree field of view gives it a much higher probability of detecting Earth-sized planets than the Hubble Space Telescope. During its nine and a half years of service, Kepler observed 530,506 stars and detected 2,662 planets.

Kepler's Legacy

Let us look at some interesting facts given by the Kepler Space Telescope.

  • Planets outnumber the stars: Kepler has proven that there are more planets than stars in our galaxy.
  • Small planets are common: More than 50 percent of the planets in the sky are likely to be small and rocky, similar to the size of the Earth. It discovered different types of planets. The most common size of the planet doesn’t exist in our solar system - a world bigger than the size of Earth and but smaller than Neptune.
  • New insights revealed about stars: Besides launching us into the golden age of exoplanets, Kepler reinvigorated the study of stars. It observed more than half a million stars over the course of its nine-year operation.

Kepler's findings allowed astronomers to group exoplanets into various types, which helps in understanding their origins. Many Super-Earths, or planets that are slightly larger than Earth having a rocky surface have been found. Of all the exoplanets discovered, roughly 70 percent were made by Kepler. It transformed our understanding of the cosmos.

Kepler's observations provided the best tracking of the bizarre patterns of dimming and brightening. It revealed that our night sky is filled with billions of hidden planets and stars. The Kepler Telescope created a legacy of more than 2,600 planets discovered outside our solar system, many of which could be potentially habitable.

After nine years of operation in deep space, the telescope's reaction control system fuel was depleted, and NASA announced its retirement on October 30, 2018. But Kepler’s legacy continues to impact and advance our understanding of the cosmos.

data.title: GROUND-BASED OBSERVATORIES
data.content:
During the 17th century, Galileo Galilei began the first major search of the night sky and modified the invention made by Hans Lippershey – the Telescope. For many generations, every great observational discovery in astronomy was discovered using telescopes sitting firmly on the ground. Ground-based observatories are used to make observations in the radio and visible light portions of the electromagnetic spectrum.

Few well-known observatories include,

  • The South African Large Telescope (SALT), the largest ground-based optical instrument in the southern hemisphere that concentrates on spectroscopic surveys,
  • Gran Telescopio Canarias (GTC) a 34-foot telescope located on La Palma of Spain's Canary Islands which uses coronagraphy to block out bright starlight and make fainter planets more visible and is capable of examining mid-range infrared light emitted by stars and planets to figure out the direction of polarized light,
  • Arecibo Observatory (Puerto Rico) is one of the world's most recognizable ground-based telescopes. It has a huge 1000-foot radio reflector dish (largest single-aperture telescope) with its spherical reflector consisting of 40,000 aluminum panels (3 feet by 6 feet). The huge reflector makes it an incredibly sensitive radio telescope, capable of homing in on a faint radio source(including distant quasars and galaxies that emit radio waves ) within a few minutes of observation.

With the advent of advanced technology, many ambitious projects are under construction right now. Few such examples include,

  • The Extremely Large Telescope (ELT) [39.2m primary mirror; 4.2m secondary mirror (diameter), the world's largest optical/near-infrared extremely large telescope constructed by the European Southern Observatory (ESO) agency in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile,
  • The Giant Magellan Telescope (GMT) - a ground-based extremely large telescope that consists of seven 8.4 m primary segments that will observe in the optical and near-infrared light spectrum. This telescope with resolving power 10 times greater than the Hubble Space Telescope with its unprecedented light gathering ability and resolution is expected to help with many fascinating questions in 21st-century astronomy such as “How did the first galaxies form? “ and “What are dark matter and dark energy that comprise most of our universe?”

  • Vera C. Rubin Observatory also referred to as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), is an astronomical observatory currently under construction in Chile. Its main task will be an astronomical survey - Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST). It has a wide-field reflecting telescope with an 8.4-meter primary mirror that will photograph the entire sky every few nights.
  • The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) in India is an advanced gravitational-wave observatory near Hingoli district in Maharashtra, that will begin operations from 2024. It would enhance the network of gravitational wave detectors worldwide.

Here is a picture of The Thirty Meter Telescope (TMT) located on Mauna Kea on the island of Hawaii.

When a telescope on the ground looks to the cosmos and takes a picture, the light it captures has first traveled through air in the atmosphere which blurs the light. That’s why ground-based telescopes cannot take super-sharp images of objects in space. Another major disadvantage is that the ground-based ones will not be able to detect frequencies and wavelengths across the entire electromagnetic spectrum because the Earth’s atmosphere absorbs a lot of infrared and ultraviolet light that passes through it.

Due to these difficulties in the ground-based telescopes, space telescopes began to emerge in the field of astronomy after a dozen generations. The trend toward space telescopes began in the 1960s when astronomers started attaching giant balloons to telescopes as a means to carry them above Earth’s lower atmosphere.

Nowadays, Space telescopes have become a common tool for innovating deep sky objects in space.

Space telescopes are great. Then why do we still build ground-based ones? Ground-based telescopes are easier to visit. Repairs and upgrading the telescopes are also much easier to carry out on the ground than in space. It is much less expensive to build a telescope on the ground than to place it into an orbit around the Earth.

They also have a much lower risk of being damaged by one of the 500,000 pieces of debris flying through the cosmos (space junk). To counter the effect of air pollution, ground-based observatories are being constructed far from big cities and at higher altitudes to avoid Atmospheric Distortion.

Whether in space or on the ground, telescopes remain the cornerstone of astronomical discovery. So, there is always hope and scope for telescopes.

data.title: Telescope's Trek
data.content:
Space never stopped alluring humans ever since they set their gaze upon the boundless sky. This was the one aspect that made us look more into whichever possible way we could. We create more and more keen paths to outer space. Through all our endeavoring ways we created a space telescope and are creating many more innovative inventions to become an observer of this vast cosmos. Space telescopes like Hubble, Aryabhata, AstroSat, and so on from the past and much more are expected in the upcoming future.

A space telescope or space observatory is a telescope located in outer space to observe distant planets, galaxies, and other astronomical objects. They are grouped by the frequency range on which they work like ultra-violet, gamma, infrared, etc. They also work in a multi-frequency range.

The above image is a sample taken by Hubble and is an example of what space telescopes are capable of. They capture breathtaking images of the space around us. There are several upcoming space observatory projects, which are being prepared by earthlings to observe our universe, roaring high up in space.

JAMES WEBB SPACE TELESCOPE (JSWT)

It is a space observatory developed by NASA along with its partners the ESA (European Space Agency) and the Canadian Space Agency. Its development started in 1996 and was planned to be launched in 2007. But due to issues like cost over-turn and delays it underwent a major redesign in 2005 and currently in 2020, completed its major milestone test series. It is expected to be launched positively on Oct. 31, 2021.

EUCLID

It is a near-infrared space telescope being developed by ESA, for observing and understanding dark matter and dark energy which make up the majority of matter in the cosmos. The mission involves investigating the distance-redshift relationship and the evolution of cosmic structures by measuring shapes and redshifts of galaxies and clusters of galaxies out to redshifts. It is expected to be launched by July-December of 2022.

PLATO

PLAnetary Transits and Oscillations of stars (PLATO) was proposed in the year 2007 and is being developed by ESA to be launched by 2026. Its major mission is to search for planetary transits across up to one million stars and to discover and characterize rocky extrasolar planets around yellow dwarf stars like our sun, subgiant stars, and red dwarf stars.

Advanced Telescope for High- Energy Astrophysics (ATHENA)

It was proposed on 24 June 2014 by ESA and is expected to be launched by 2028. It is an X-Ray observatory. The primary goal of the mission is to map hot gas structures, determine their physical properties, and search for supermassive black holes.

        These are some of the space observatories that are expected to probe space soon and many more are being developed. Space telescopes are to make our space exploration much more interesting and take us one step closer to unraveling the marvelous mysteries and miracles of space.

data.title: AstroSatâ€™s Journey among the Stars
data.content:
The Indian Tricolour flies high as the country’s first multi-wavelength Astronomical Space Observatory, AstroSat, celebrates five years of being in orbit around the Earth and making exceptional contributions to the field of Deep Space Astronomy. Join us as we look back into AstroSat’s journey of becoming an Extraordinary Eye in the Sky.

THE LAUNCH

The 1513 kg space observatory was placed into a 650 km orbit, inclined at an angle of 6° to the equator by the iron horse of the Indian Space Program: the PSLV series of launch vehicles; with the one that launched AstroSat being an XL variant. AstroSat was joined by 6 other satellites from the USA, Indonesia and Canada; thus, continuing to demonstrate the trust in India’s launching capabilities. The satellites were launched from the First Launch Pad (FLP) of Satish Dhawan Space Center (SDSC), Sriharikota, Karnataka.

WHY ASTROSAT?

The radiation emitted by an astronomical source indicates the physical state of the matter, especially it’s temperature. Observing the same source in different wavelengths provides a detailed insight into its various constituents, present at various states. The reason to have observatories up in space is that our planet’s atmosphere shields a large portion of this radiation from entering and this makes us opaque to the greater part of the EM spectrum.

AstroSat was specially built for this purpose. It is capable of simultaneously observing entities in the X-Ray, Visible and UV band allowing it to peer deep into some of the most energetic sources in the Universe: Active Galactic Nuclei, White Dwarf stars, X-Ray Binaries and Transient High Energy Sources such as Gamma Ray Bursts and Supernova Explosions.

Andromeda galaxies observed in different wavelengths

UNDER THE HOOD

The cubical-shaped body of AstroSat houses 5 sensitive payloads that enable the satellite to perform multi-wavelength astronomy. The body is coupled with two solar panels (2100 W power) for the spacecraft’s operation. In addition to this, it possesses a thermal subsystem that keeps the instruments at a relatively cooler temperature to significantly reduce electronic noise. The satellite re-orients itself using precise gyroscopes and star sensors that allow it to home in on intended targets.

ASTROSAT: An Infographic

The ISRO Telemetry, Tracking, and Command Network (ISTRAC), Bangalore is the ground segment responsible for operating the satellite and receiving all the observational data from it. The data are archived and managed by the Indian Space Science Data Centre (ISSDC), Bangalore.

  • Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope (UVIT): The UVIT comprises a pair of telescopes with a field of view of 0.5° and a very high spatial resolution of 1.8 arc seconds. One of the two can observe in the visible (320-550 nm) and Near UV (NUV: 200-300 nm) and the other in the Far UV (FUV: 130-180 nm) band. UVIT is used for constructing deep field images (images of a specific region observed for long periods of time that are stacked together)
  • The UVIT’s prime targets are Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN: Galaxies powered by supermassive black holes), Young hot stars that emit in the UV region, White Dwarf stars, X-Ray Binaries (Star accreting around a neutron star or black hole), Globular and Open Star Clusters, etc
  • Large Area X-ray Proportional Counters (LAXPC):  The LAXPC is a set of 3 counters that operate in the hard X-ray band (3-80 keV). It is used for X-ray spectroscopy and to precisely record the time intervals between successive events (up to a precision of 10 µs!).
  • The LAXPC is primarily used to perform studies on X-ray binaries (X-ray binaries consist of a neutron star (or a black hole; both very compact and dense bodies) with a companion star).
  • Soft X-ray Telescope (SXT): The SXT is a telescope designed to image objects in the soft X-ray band (energies between 0.3 - 8 keV). The SXT focuses X-ray photons, incidents on it and it is collected by a Charge-Coupled Device (CCD). The CCD is cooled to -80 °C to avoid noise photons from contaminating the data.
  • The SXT’s prime targets include X-ray binaries, Galaxy Clusters, Quasars (a galaxy with an energetic core), SuperNova Remnants (SNRs; the residual matter from a stellar explosion), etc.
  • Cadmium Zinc Telluride Imager (CZTI): The CZTI is a broadband X-ray detector (0.3-100 keV). It operates in the Soft as well as Hard X-ray region and is used in tandem with LAXPC and SXT.
  • Its prime targets include X-ray binaries and AGNs. In addition to these, CZTI is capable of observing Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs; energies > 100 keV) in great detail.
  • Scanning Sky Monitor (SSM): The SSM constantly has an eye on the sky, looking out for transient X-ray sources i.e., strong sources of X-ray that last only for a fraction of a second. If it comes across one, it directs the satellite to reorient itself pointing at the source.
  • Charged Particle Monitor (CPM): The CPM constantly monitors the environment around AstroSat and looks out for charged particles as the instruments onboard AstroSat are sensitive and exposing them to sudden fluxes of charged particles might damage them.

The Universe- through the Eyes of AstroSat

From top to bottom (column-wise): Wings of the butterfly Nebula, Andromeda galaxy, The Witch's Broom- a part of Cygnus Loop Nebula in UV, Globular Cluster NGC 288, Galaxy NGC 300, UV tails of Atoms for Peace Galaxy, Galaxy Cluster Abell 2256, Spiral Galaxy NGC 2336, Andromeda Galaxy, Galaxy NGC 1365, Tycho Supernova Remnant in X-Ray, Globular Cluster NGC 1851.

data.title: Summary of Interview with Dr. Kanak Saha
data.content:
INTERVIEWEE: Dr. Kanak Saha

INTERVIEWERS: Ashwin Kumar M, 2nd year, Chemical Engineering, ACTech

                         Muthuannalakshmi A, 4th year, IT, CEG

MODERATOR: Subhiksha N, 4th year, Industrial Engineering, CEG

The stars above the Indian sub-continent shine brighter than ever before, as India's first multi-wavelength astronomy satellite AstroSat - India’s very own and only space telescope celebrates its fifth anniversary. In celebration of that, we are super glad to have Dr. Kanak Saha as our very first guest in this “Titan” Talks- an informative interview series. Dr. Kanak Saha is an associate professor at Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics (IUCAA), Pune, whose primary research is focused on Galaxies: their structure, formation, and evolution. Dr. Saha and his team recently hit the headlines bringing the spotlight on AstroSat for the discovery of one of the farthest star galaxies in the universe, estimated to be located 9.3 billion light-years away.

Here’s an exclusive insight into the excerpts from the interview:

1. As AstroSat turns 5 on the 28th, how excited are you, about India’s endeavor in the field of Deep Space Astronomy?

Dr. Saha: AstroSat is already turning five years old. In some senses, it’s getting old. I feel rather sad than excited because of its (designed for a) finite lifetime. I would love for it to live and function much longer. I am very glad for ISRO for flying the AstroSat and so far, it’s working pretty well even at this moment. It’s very nice that it has been completed five years and remains functional.

Ashwin: Yes sir, we hope for the same too.

Anu: Or we hope for similar upcoming missions like AstroSat-2.

Dr. Saha: There are talks going on (regarding future missions). There are no official announcements yet. But talks for a UV mission called INSIST is in its early stage of planning. It will take its own course of time to come onto the surface.

2. Before dwelling on the aspects of your recent discovery, could you brief our viewers about its significance?

Dr. Saha: The recently discovered galaxy is called AUDFs01. This is the only and a very distant galaxy so far from which we are able to record extreme UV light at a wavelength of 600A.

Why is it important you ask?

It is because we know that any light/any photon that has a wavelength below 900 Å or if the energy is greater than 13.6eV, then it can split a hydrogen atom into a proton and an electron i.e., it can ionize hydrogen atom. Something like this was required when the universe was going through a re-ionization period which in the first billion years after the universe came into existence. When the first galaxies formed, they were emitting a lot of such kinds of extreme UV photons which were re-ionizing the rest of hydrogen gas. But we do not have any observational evidence of those first (ancient) galaxies. We wanted to know what they would look like. Since such galaxies cannot be observed, we looked for them in the nearby observable universe.

AUDFs01 could be one such firstly formed galaxy since it emits a lot of extreme UV photons, we have calculated it to be around at least 20% to its surroundings. Once we find more such galaxies, we will get an idea of how they looked like and what caused the re-ionization of the Universe.

3. What gave AstroSat the edge over Hubble in this discovery?

Dr. Saha: The way it goes is that we can look into far away galaxies through the deep field. We can create deep images of some patch of the sky which is observed multiple times repeatedly to create a deep field image (e.g.: Hubble deep field). Hubble deep field was made in (spectrums) such as near optical, near infra-red, near UV. Through the deep field, even fainter galaxies that are farther away can be seen.

The first step we made was creating an AstroSat UV Deep field- AUDF, using Astrosat data from over 28 hours of observations. The images collected in every orbit were stacked together using algorithms and the deep image was created. The image turned out to be very deep in which we noticed an extremely faint object. AUDFs01 is a galaxy that is almost at the near end of the observational limit. If you look at the same region of the sky using HST’s (Hubble space telescope) far-ultraviolet filter, there is a lot of background noise in it. We had better control over the noise, I wouldn’t say we are better than Hubble, but somehow, we were able to capture the image with higher noise control.

Ashwin: Can this be attributed to the fact that Hubble’s last servicing mission was done long ago and AstroSat is a relatively new instrument?

Dr. Saha: Not exactly. Hubble’s detector has its own characteristics. There accompanies a dark current which is a dominant source of noise in Hubble’s images. As the observational run prolongs, the temperature of the system rises consequently increasing the dark current as well.

4. How do astronomers ascertain that the UV radiation picked up by UVIT is emitted by sources belonging to the Epoch of Re-ionization?

I would like to clarify that this source does not belong to the epoch of re-ionization. This has a redshift of 1.4 while the epoch of re-ionization ended at a redshift of 6 and started at a much higher redshift range of 10. This galaxy came at a much later stage. The only similarity (with ancient galaxies) is what I explained earlier.

Ashwin: So, This AUDFs01 is an analog of a galaxy that we could expect to see in the epoch of Re-ionization. And its properties will be a key for astronomers such as you to study the formation of early galaxies.

Dr. Saha: Yes, exactly.

5. Having created the AstroSat UV Deep Field (AUDF), could you highlight its salient features? Which part of the sky and what sources does it constitute?

Dr. Saha: This is where the Hubble Deep Field is currently looking. So, this field has become very very popular. Every single telescope I know observed GOODS-South field. So, it's famous. I also thought that why not point to AstroSat and focus on an observational plan for looking at the deep field in the GOODS-South field. It is also known as Chandra Deep Field south. Because Chandra, the X-Ray satellite also created a deep field image in X-ray background. It (GOODS-South field) has an enormous amount of data spanning over a very huge electromagnetic spectrum starting from X-Ray by Chandra, AstroSat- deepest UV field, HST, Spitzer space telescope, Herschel space observatory, and lots and lots of telescopes who at some point of time in their operational period have observed this part of the sky.

AstroSat’s observational field area is much bigger when compared with the original GOODS-South field area. It is also not easy to find out about AUDFs01 on the internet as we have just coined the term for it. But you can locate it by its coordinates and look it up in the astronomical database. The selection of this galaxy was not random. We looked at over 1517 galaxies whose exact redshift was known to us and filtered them based on certain conditions to around 948 galaxies, which were located in the Hubble Extreme deep field region- a very tiny part of the sky in the Hubble deep field and so on. We analyzed the different spectral properties of these galaxies. We then filtered these galaxies in such a way that within the PSF (Point spread function) of AstroSat, there are no other objects. If that were the case, we cannot determine for sure which is emitting the light. This gave us only 37 out of 1517 galaxies. Then, the galaxies whose signal-to-noise ratio was at least greater than 3 were prioritized. This narrowed it down to 2. From the two, we chose this particular galaxy because of the reason mentioned above (extreme UV photon emission). The other object is yet to be analyzed. It is not an easy feat to emit in such an extreme UV region. The photons firstly cannot easily escape the galaxy. Even when one does, it usually gets absorbed by the gas surrounding the galaxy or by any other countless number of other objects en route to our galaxy. So, registering photons of this particular energy is not so common. Hopefully, things will change for the better in the future and more such observations can be made easily.

6. What are some of your favorite moments as being part of a global research team in making this ‘exciting’ discovery?

We were all very excited the first day we made this observation almost two years ago. The other exciting part was creating the Deep field and comparing it with other space telescope’s data from various different spectra. I used to spend days simply surfing over the deep image I created. There’s so much to see in a single image!!

7. In recent times, it has been increasingly difficult for the common man to obtain an unobtrusive view of the starry night sky. Due to several reasons, the most important of them being Urban Light Pollution; and not to mention pesky satellite constellations. In such scenarios, space telescopes have always been a glimmer of hope. Hubble is considered an effective public outreach tool. To what extent do you believe that space observatories serve this purpose and how effective has AstroSat been in the above context?

Space astronomy is a costly affair that is relatively very large compared to what you can do from the ground. But it is not that. There are certain scientific restrictions(limitations) that force us to look from space rather than the ground. For example, UV rays will not be able to penetrate as effectively to enable sharp observations similarly for X-Rays and Infrared observation. The window for observation from the ground is very narrow- optical astronomy. That’s why there are so many ground-based facilities available for optical astronomy purposes. Due to urbanization, they do get affected. We need to go to remote villages to even look at dark skies these days. At the same time, these ground-based observatories cannot be replaced as they are very costly to be done from space.

As said earlier, there’s also a scientific need to study from space. UV astronomy cannot be done from the ground.

8. How do you think space astronomy differs from ground-based astronomy?

Ground-based astronomy is essential and irreplaceable as of now. One very encouraging aspect of astronomy is that the data is available for public use. It is serving a huge community with lots of people trained in it.

Space astronomy is done for a purpose. It is not done to replace ground-based astronomy as certain things are not accessible from the ground

9. Discoveries such as yours are inspirational to all the youngsters dreaming to research about the stars. What is your message for all those students?

I have been working on this since 2016; it has been four years since then. Before this, as a researcher, I had gone through 15 years of research activities, gaining experience steadily. I was able to do all this as I had basically studied Physics. B.Sc. and then my Masters in Physics.

I remember doing amateur Astronomy when I was in school. Making a 6-inch telescope, I just keep staring at Pleiades (the Pleiades open star cluster) or maybe look up at Jupiter or Saturn; the most interesting objects in the sky. I did a Masters’s project on Ferro-Electric Liquid crystal. And later on, because of my childhood fascination, I chose Astrophysics as my Ph.D. course.

To all the youngsters, if I have to give any advice, I would say that you can excel in the subject that you are pursuing right now. There is always a scope to come to it (the field of Astronomy). For example, I studied Physics, but I know many of my colleagues who had studied engineering and have become very good astronomers.

This (our discovery) can only be taken as a motivation; a sense of inspiration. If more such discoveries (in astronomy) are made in our country, it will definitely inspire people. I believe such discoveries leave behind a good note with the people.

If they (people) wish to explore more about this field, their efforts must not be at the cost of their studies or their goals and what they wish to achieve in life.

Anu: Thank you, sir. That was all we had today. Subhiksha, would you please deliver the endnote?

Subhiksha: Thank you Anu. Sir, it has been an immense pleasure interviewing you today. We would like to express our sincere gratitude to Dr. Kanak Saha for accepting our requisition for this interview. Thank you, sir. I am sure that this exclusive insight into various aspects of AstroSat will be very informative and encouraging to all our student followers.

By referring to a remark from Harsha Bhogle’s podcast series: Mission ISRO, I would like to conclude this session by saying that Your discovery has been a classic underdog story for ISRO, that has put AstroSat among the league of masterpieces such as Hubble. We are eagerly looking forward to more such discoveries.

Thank you, Sir. Thank you, Ashwin and Anu.

data.title: MYSTERY!
data.content:
I lay star gazing

And Whoosh

I found a shooting star

And swish

I felt a sudden breeze

And blink

I was transported

And wink

I was back on Earth.

What happened?

I was wondering.

Was that a campfire?

It was bewildering.

Was that a tent?

My mind was quizzing.

Were they aliens?

My heart was beating.

Was it reality?

I questioned snoring.

It’s still a mystery.

Whether it’s reality or a lie,

Without a conclusion

I slept staring at the vast sky.

~ Art and poem by M. Juvairiya Farsana (mjf)

data.title: Under the same sky!
data.content:
Stars are the same,

So is the breeze,

All carrying your scent,

Making me freeze.

Longings are plenty,

Your breath is far away,

At least we are under the same sky,

Under a common roof with patience we stay.

~ Art and poem by M. Juvairiya Farsana (mjf)

data.title: Dreaming under the Northern Lights!
data.content: ~ Art by M. Juvairiya Farsana (mjf)

data.title: SETI: Are we really alone in the universe?
data.content:
Figure - 1, Artistic description of outer space.

We have spent countless hours staring at the night sky, wondering if we’re the only intelligent life forms in the whole universe. We are all eager, waiting for an answer to this question. SETI is trying to find the answer to this question that remains in our minds.

SETI (‘Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence’), is a search for intelligent life forms in outer space, mainly based on the belief that advanced civilizations in the cosmos are broadcasting signals for other intelligent life forms to detect.

SETI mainly focuses on the transmission of radio waves from outer space. Though many unorganized searches began since the inception of radio in the early 1900s,  more formal searches began with global effort around the 1970s.

Early Origins:

In the early 1900s, few scientists claimed that the strange radio signals they received from outer space could be of a potential Martian origin. But this wasn’t accepted by many, and other scientists started to give different explanations that this could be some naturally occurring phenomenon in space. As radio technology was relatively new at that time, they weren’t clear about the outcomes of the technology.

Figure - 2, American Astronomer Frank Drake.

The first modern SETI project (‘Project Ozma’) was conceived by astronomer Frank Drake in 1960, which aimed to search for signs of potential life by listening to radio signals close to hydroxyl radical and hydrogen spectral lines. The project was conducted with a massive telescope of 85ft that examined the stars – Tau Ceti and Epsilon Eridani. But unfortunately, nothing significant was discovered.

Around the same time, a radio telescope named the “Big Ear''(formerly known as Ohio State University SETI project) was constructed by Ohio State University which used a flat-plane telescope fitted with a parabolic reflector. (figure – 3).

WOW Signal:

Figure – 3, the “Big Ear” Radio Telescope Observatory in Delaware city, Ohio.

Another big leap occurred in 1977, when “Big Ear” received the “Wow! Signal” - a narrowband signal which originated from the constellation of Sagittarius. It came to be known as the “Wow! Signal” because the astronomer Jerry Ehman who discovered the signal wrote the comment “Wow!” on the side of the computer printout of the signal he was reviewing, (figure – 4). The signal lasted for 72 seconds, and by far remains the most likely contender of an artificial origin. But this signal was never detected again. Many theories were put forward to explain the likely source of this signal, but none of them have been widely accepted by the scientific community.

Figure – 4, the computer printout of the “Wow! Signal”.

Modern SETI Projects:

Figure - 5, Arecibo Observatory, Puerto Rico.

Soon after this, many SETI projects like SENTINEL, META came up. As computer processing power evolved greatly over the same time, SETI projects started using techniques like Digital Signal Processing (DSP), Fast Fourier Transform (FTT) to analyze signals.

Despite heavy criticism, NASA started the Microwave Observing Program (MOP) in 1992. MOP carried out many targeting searches at neighboring stars, using its network of radio antennas including the Arecibo Observatory at Puerto Rico. But its funding was withdrawn within one year of its start. MOP was renamed “Project Phoenix” and was revived by the newly formed SETI institute based in California with private funding. Since then, SETI institute has collaborated with other radio telescopes and astronomers worldwide to continue its radio searches.

In the present day, many SETI programs are still searching for signs of intelligent life forms in outer space. Radio astronomers and amateur astronomers are actively contributing to SETI by pooling their resources of radio dishes, computing power, and other equipment with a network of other astronomers across the globe irrespective of borders, the quest of eagerness drives them to discover new realms.

Edited by: Zafirah Aneez,

        2nd year, Ceramic Technology, ACTech

data.title: INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION- HUMANITYâ€™S WINGED OUTPOST
data.content:
It’s been twenty whole years since humanity decided to take ‘the next big step’ in its ever-alluring relationship with outer space by moving into a flying condo that floats 240 km above the surface. That’s right- It’s been twenty years since humans started living on the ‘International Space Station’.

The station’s paramount purpose is to be used for conducting a myriad of researches in many different disciplines, results of which could potentially help us in getting our express ticket to mars and beyond.

Over the course of the years, more than 3000 experiments have been conducted on board the ISS. They can be broadly classified under

· Biology and Biotechnology

· Earth and Space science

· Human Research

· Physical Science

· Technology

As mankind prepares to storm foreign lands planets, the main concern regarding the successful transportation of people(alive) will be

………………………….............................…………………………………………

FOOD!! ( pfft…You thought Oxygen?)

        One of the predominant researches going up there is to figure out an efficient way to grow stuff that will keep us up and running on long interstellar journeys. Astronauts aboard the ISS grow green plants in hopes of a) Eating them b) getting fresh O2 (it’s a win-win!) and c) studying plant growth in microgravity.

The Vegetable Production System, known as Veggie, is a space garden about the size of a carry-on piece of luggage residing on the space station. So far, the garden has hosted lettuce, Chinese cabbage, mizuna mustard, red Russian kale, and zinnia flowers.

Zinnia Bouquet captured by astronaut Scott Kelly.

Astronaut Serena harvesting on ISS

There’s another growth chamber called “ Advanced plant habitat” the size of a mini-fridge, designed to test which growth conditions plants prefer in space and provides specimens with a larger root and shoot area.

        What’s a lab without some lab rats? The effects of long-term radiation exposure were studied on rodents and mice that have been to space and back. They can be used to study longevity, cancer development, and gene mutations in humans. Other organisms that hitched a ride to space include ants (or ANT-stronauts ~ data from this study will help develop complex algorithms for robotics), squids, flatworms (regeneration study), and several microbes (to analyze their behavior in space).

Space ant colony

        Orbiting at an average altitude of 400km, ISS becomes a unique vantage point for collecting earth and space science data of features such as glaciers, agricultural fields, cities, and coral reefs, etc., which can be layered with other sources of data, such as orbiting satellites, to compile the most comprehensive information available.

ISS also hosts a few cutting edge scientific instruments such as NASA’s Cold atom lab-a suitcase-size instrument that enables the study of quantum gases cooled to near-absolute zero, Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer- a dark matter detector and a 3D BioFabrication Facility -a 3-D printer that allows the construction of complex biological systems made up of layers of soft tissue.

Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer(AMS)

NASA astronaut Jessica Meirworks with the Life Sciences Glove Box.          

        While it seems like every research undertaken is done with the aim of providing for humans in deep space travels, studies concerning more pressing real-world issues are also ongoing simultaneously. Extensive studies on finding a cure for Parkinson’s and cancer by growing high-quality protein crystals are being undertaken by the astronauts residing in the station. Many applications of the already conducted studies help in solving real-world issues such as building improved vaccines, monitoring disasters, advancement in medical devices, improving indoor air quality, and most importantly offer a better understanding of human physiology( a famous example for this would be the twins' study conducted by NASA).

Astronaut Sunita William running on a Treadmill

        ISS represents the acme of the world’s technological growth over the past few decades. Studies that are conducted on a place where it costs a million dollars for pizza delivery, might have not just yet found the miracle cure for cancer or proof of alien life forms - but they will be indubitably crucial for the evolution of humanity into an interplanetary species.

Science has always been mankind’s first love and will continue to be so until the day it perishes. ISS remained, remains, and will remain until it is decommissioned to make sure that it won’t be on Earth.

The View from Cupola!

“To confine our attention to terrestrial matters would be to limit the human spirit.” – Stephen Hawking

data.title: Tying the Knots for Astronomy and Engineering
data.content:
Curiosity – to know more, explore further, understand better, utilize efficiently. Space is the foremost word that we connect with curiosity. Because no matter how many thousand brains work together, it remains a mystery and a question of uncertainty.

“The important thing is not to stop questioning. Curiosity has its own reason for existing. One cannot help but be in awe when he contemplates the mysteries of eternity, of life, of the marvelous structure of reality. It is enough if one tries merely to comprehend a little of this mystery every day. Never lose a holy curiosity.” 

-Albert Einstein.

In the recent past, our curiosity has led the way to interdisciplinary studies and research which turned out to be an unfathomable success. Integrals alone can’t solve the entire math problem; reactions alone don’t account for entire chemistry and physics alone can’t teach us astronomy. There needs to be an interdisciplinary approach.

                                                             

Earlier, Natural Sciences and Engineering were thought to be light-years apart. But now, engineering plays a vital role in astronomy – the most important being instrumentation.

To understand the link between astronomy and engineering better, let us take an oversight at NASA. Highly experienced astrophysicists, astrobiologists, and space researchers at NASA analyze the origins of the universe, study the habitats in other planets and their potential to harbor life and other such factors on a daily basis. Their primary source for such information is data collected from satellites and rovers. And it is the engineers who have the hands behind the designing and manufacturing of these machines. Even the sensitive components inside them – chip, circuit boards, sensors, reflectors –  are all designed by engineers. And for the rovers and satellites to collect information and communicate with the base, it requires them to be programmed by computer science engineers. Hence, space research cannot advance without assistance from engineers.

Moreover, not just do an engineer and an astronomer need to work together, but even an astronomer needs to have basic technical skills like programming to crunch data, surveying skills to analyze data, and tech-software knowledge to come to a solid conclusion, and nothing better than a basic knowledge of at least one of the engineering disciplines to acquire these skills.

To sum up, just knowing basic calculus, laws of physics, and the big bang theory, one cannot contribute to any revolutionary discovery or innovation. Understanding basic technical stuff and knowing how to utilize it for space exploration and research, is what makes an efficient astronomer. So, if you are an engineering student with a passion for space sciences, it’s still not late. Pursue your ultimate dream because someday in the near future, the old engineering tricks may lay down the seeds for the next big innovation in astronomy.

Stay Curious 🌠!

Edited by: Nitish K. S.

data.title: Handshake with Heat!
data.content:
If you saw a heat wave, would you wave back? I guess not! That’s why you need a heat shield…
.

A heat shield is any material that prevents heat from escaping into the environment. Simply put, a heat shield is any type of barrier that limits the penetration of heat. For example, if you place the TV near a fireplace, the heat from the flame can be absorbed by the TV cabinet and could damage both the cabinet and the internal components. By placing a heat shield between the heat source and the TV, you can protect the TV from overheating while enjoying a hot flame and your favorite TV shows.

HOW DO HEAT SHIELDS WORK?

.

Heat shields protect structures from extreme temperatures and thermal gradients specific to different heat issues.

Types of heat issues are:

  • Conduction heat transfers heat from one object to another by direct contact.
  • Convection heat occurs when heat is transferred between a solid and a moving liquid and/or gas.
  • Radiant heat is the heat radiated from a heat source to a component that is not in direct contact with the heat source.

.

Ways to mitigate them:

Heatsink: A heatsink is a special fabric or coating that removes heat efficiently. Thermal solutions that use heat sinks help protect objects on the other side of the shield by reducing the amount of heat passing through the shield.

Reflection: Reflective heat shields are the most common products used in thermal degradation. These types of products act as a barrier by transferring heat from the barrier surface away from the protected area or object.

Insulation: Finally, products like exhaust heat shields use insulation to help keep the heat at its source. Collecting heat at the source is the most effective way to improve performance and protect components.

WHY HEAT SHIELDS IN SPACECRAFT?
.

.

When entering or exiting the Earth's atmosphere, spacecraft experience severe friction or atmospheric drag. Due to the very high speed and acceleration of the spacecraft, the frictional force is very high. Due to these resistances, a huge amount of energy is dissipated and the dissipated energy is mainly converted into heat. Without the shield, the spaceship would burn in the blink of an eye. So, heat shields are used to protect spacecraft.

Elements such as silica are used in the shield. They absorb most of the heat generated by friction. Generally, when we go against friction, the surface temperature becomes very high and it can catch fire as well. In the case of spacecraft, the shields act as heaters that, when absorbed, give off heat to the atmosphere. The hard thermal shield until recently was made of steel, but now it is often made of aluminum.

SOME APPLICATIONS IN SPACECRAFT AND SHUTTLES
.

  • A thermal soak heat shield uses an insulating material to absorb and radiate heat from the spacecraft structure. This type was used in the Space Shuttle, which consists of fiberglass tiles over most of the surface of the vehicle, with carbon-carbon material reinforced at the points of greatest thermal stress, the nose, and the leading edges of the wing. Damage to this material on one wing caused the 2003 Space Shuttle Columbia disaster.
    .


.

 .

  • An ablative heat shield consists of a layer of plastic whose outer surface is heated to form a gas that dissipates heat by convection. These shields were used on the Mercury, Gemini, and Apollo spacecraft.
    .

 

So the next time you see a spacecraft successfully take off from Earth or land on another planet, it is due to an exceptionally and meticulously designed Heat Shield!  

Edited by: Nitish K S

data.Name: Swadesh B
data.Description: I am a final year CS student with deep interests in astronomy. I am a frequent star gazer with a rubix complex. I believe the future of astronomy is in data science and would like to contribute to field of astronomy with my expertise in Computer Science.

data.Name: M. Ashwin Kumar
data.Description: Considers science as a "way-of-life". Sustainability freak. Intends to lead a minimalistic lifestyle. Very conscious about waste disposal. Prefers to ride a bicycle than a BMW! Always eager to learn science to understand the inner workings of nature. A proud Linux user. Takes interest in Van Goghs. Likes to gaze at the stars and admire the infinite beauty that nature beholds. Believes that his infinitesimally insignificant contributions would help achieve "<1.5°C" .

data.Name: Vani Padmakumar
data.Description: Even as a kid, one thing I always kept asking my mom as she held me on hip hop trying to feed me was about the vastness of the stars and the big cheese ball like object called the moon. It was something that I was always fascinated by mainly because of the great potential for exploration in that field. Itâ€™s safe to say that we have just scratched the surface of the things that we can discover in space, from new planets to even scary aliens but as i have grown mature i wanted to know the ideas and theories behind stellar evolution, bigbang theory, etc cetera about which I have been wondering from my childhood.

data.Name: Sai Krishnan.S
data.Description: I am a keen lover of astronomy and I have been working in Astro club for the past 2 years. Astronomy has its own glory and it's discoveries oscillate every second. I am updating myself with the latest scientific information by reading various journals and research papers. I work really hard and strive towards excellence. I will always complete my work within the deadline & show my sincerity and dedication in whichever work I do.

data.Name: Suvetha Devi
data.Description:
I am a 3rd year student studying M.sc integrated (Information Technology)-5 years programme.
in CEG Guindy campus. I love to learn and explore more about Machine learning and Data science which is my field of study.
Besides my exploration , I have interest in Design and also One of my hobbies is to keep starring at stars and space and wondering and thinking of it.
So, I thought for a chance to make my hobbies implemented officially. Fortunately, I get to know about Astro Club one year before. There I was able to implement my favorite hobbies and interests together. And so I travelled happily here for more than a year. I think  my interests and desires are getting fulfilled here. I am an introvert and I do not speak out anything but after an year of  travel, I think I have become an perfect extrovert.
I think this much of  exploration and experience makes a great and precious footprints in My Life of journey.

data.Name: Sridhar M
data.Description: I am just an ordinary boy next door,ofcourse an engineering student,carrying astonishing dreams in me about the moons, stars and the infinite space itself.I like good books and movies that make me feel bad. I am not addicted to them but it is more like a drug to me.It may look like I am doing nothing, but in my head, I am very busy.Life can be very complicated sometimes that is why i always take the simple way out of it.

data.Name: Sayid Zafirah A
data.Description:
Content writer and a blogger, who is passionate about writing. Do not stress, if the job is assigned to me. Finds her solace by just diving into random thoughts.
Relatable quote: Sleep enough, to never give up on your dreams.

data.Name: Sandhya G
data.Description: I am a third-year chemical engineering student at Anna University. A Dynamic and fun-loving person who lights up the places I go. I always try to explore new things and enjoy everything to the maximum. Space is a space that drags me into its wonders like a spell.  I particularly enjoy space-related sci-fi movies and love to know more about whatever piques my curiosity.  In all, I am a person who likes to cheer up my surroundings in my way.

data.Name: Shershon A J
data.Description: Two things always capture my attention. The way the universe unravels itself in front of our naked eyes and the way we have been unravelling its mysteries and communicating it through the generations, since time immemorial. Exhilarated that I could get the taste of both and contribute my part to the ever-growing astrophile community.

data.Name: Aishwarya G
data.Description: I am an astrophile and star gazing makes me feel so relaxed. I was always interested in space and I do believe that solving the mysteries of space is important as it might be of some use to solve the problems we have on Earth as well. As a student pursuing Biotechnology and my passion for space exploration makes me curious and want to learn more about the space biology and the space biotechnology which is a budding field.

data.Name: Syed Junaid Ali B
data.Description: I am a second year CSE guy studying in CEG, Guindy, trying to explore more on artificial intelligence and machine learning. I am also a space enthusiast with an interest to know more on cosmology and science. I am a perfect extrovert with an introverted psychology. Trying to stay unique from the rest has been my hobby. Original since March 9 2002. My game is beyond pain. Neither my character nor my curiosity decreases. That is me.
data.Designation: Social Media and Marketing Junior Executive

data.Name: Abhisri.M
data.Description: A third-year student who is currently studying ACTech B.tech leather technology. My passion for Astronomy started when I heard Twinkle, twinkle little star  rhymes for the first time. It lit my curiosity about various things such as where I live, why are the stars and moon hang in the sky only at night, and the sun in the morning. Then, I started to quench my thirst through books, videos, and TV channels like National Geographic, Discovery channel, etc. One fine day, I came across interesting news that Kalpana Chawla was the first Indian woman to go to space. I was super inspired that I wanted to share the same passion for astronomy and would like to follow her footpaths on becoming an astronaut. After having such thoughts, I started to pick up interest in cosmology, constellations, mythologies, and folklore associated with celestial bodies, other habitable planets, and missions related to intergalactic voyages, etc. To keep following my passion and meet people who share similar interests in space, I joined our Astro club of CEG. It allowed me to make contributions and learn many new things.
data.Designation: Social media and Marketing Executive Head
